body_html:
Ah ok - if you pip installed the whl created by the methods described on that page, then switch to the virtualenv or conda environment into which you installed it, unless you installed it into the system using sudo pip ....

Then, make sure you change directories out of the tensorflow source root, as this has been reported by some people to end up with Python trying to import from the source tree; at that point, the Python script should be able to find all imports without problem.

That still isn't finding the imports, lemme know what commit of master or branch you pulled your source from.
body_text:
Ah ok - if you pip installed the whl created by the methods described on that page, then switch to the virtualenv or conda environment into which you installed it, unless you installed it into the system using sudo pip ....
Then, make sure you change directories out of the tensorflow source root, as this has been reported by some people to end up with Python trying to import from the source tree; at that point, the Python script should be able to find all imports without problem.
That still isn't finding the imports, lemme know what commit of master or branch you pulled your source from.
body:
Ah ok - if you pip installed the whl created by the methods described on that page, then switch to the virtualenv or conda environment into which you installed it, unless you installed it into the system using `sudo pip ...`.

Then, make sure you change directories out of the tensorflow source root, as this has been reported by some people to end up with Python trying to import from the source tree; at that point, the Python script should be able to find all imports without problem.

That still isn't finding the imports, lemme know what commit of master or branch you pulled your source from.
